overview: This measure now appropriates funds to the Department of Human Services, instead of the Office of the Governor, for the continued implementation of the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program. [169] [181] The bill was amended to require all kauhale projects to be connected to public utilities and authorizes them to charge monthly rents of no more than thirty per cent of the area median income level. [170] [180]
appropriations: While the appropriation amounts in the bill remain unspecified, Governor Green’s Executive Biennium Budget requested $50 million (Public testimony requests $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) each year for Fiscal Years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for the Kauhale Initiative. [45] Additionally, the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) has submitted testimony requesting $175,000 (Public testimony requests $175,000.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) for one full-time equivalent housing finance specialist position. [5]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Governor’s Executive Biennium Budget request of $50 million (Public testimony requests $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) each year for the Kauhale Initiative provides a basis for estimating the potential fiscal impact of the bill's blank appropriations. [45] This funding level is intended to help achieve the Governor’s goal of establishing 30 kauhale villages across the state by the end of 2026. [46]
agency_impact: A significant amendment changes the appropriation expending agency for the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program from the Office of the Governor to the Department of Human Services. [181] This transfers the primary administrative and fiscal responsibility for these programs to DHS. [163] [165] HHFDC reiterates its request for $175,000 (Public testimony requests $175,000.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) for one full-time housing finance specialist position to administer provisions related to supportive housing projects. [5]
economic_impact: The authorization for the kauhale initiative to charge monthly rents of no more than thirty per cent of the area median income level will have a direct economic effect on residents. [163] [180] Studies have shown that by providing housing for chronically homeless individuals will not only improve overall health outcomes but will also help to save taxpayers millions of dollars in health care costs. [43]
policy_impact: This measure has been amended to establish new requirements for the Kauhale Initiative, stipulating that all kauhale projects must be connected to public utilities, including water, sewer, and electricity. [162] [180] It also introduces a new policy authorizing the collection of monthly rents, capped at thirty per cent of the area median income level. [163] [180] Furthermore, the measure changes the expending agency for the Kauhale and Ohana Zones appropriations to the Department of Human Services. [181]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The appropriations for the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program will now be expended by the Department of Human Services for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [163] [165] The Governor's office has requested $50 million (Public testimony requests $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) annually for the Kauhale Initiative to support its goal of establishing 30 kauhale villages by the end of 2026. [45] [46] The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) has requested $175,000 (Public testimony requests $175,000.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) for one FTE housing finance specialist I position. [5] The new requirement for public utility connections may increase the initial capital costs for kauhale projects. [162] The authorization to charge rent may generate some offsetting revenue for the program's operating costs. [163]
operating_revenue_impact: The measure now authorizes the kauhale initiative to charge monthly rents of no more than thirty per cent of the area median income level. [163] [180] This provision is expected to generate a new stream of operating revenue to support the continued operation of kauhale projects. [160]
capital_expenditure_impact: A new requirement has been added providing that all kauhale projects shall be connected to public utilities, including water, sewer, and electricity. [162] [180] This will likely increase the capital expenditure costs associated with the development of new kauhale sites to ensure compliance with this provision. [162]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: Key changes in this version of the measure include transferring the expending agency for the Kauhale Initiative and Ohana Zones Pilot Program from the Office of the Governor to the Department of Human Services. [181] New requirements were added mandating that kauhale projects be connected to public utilities and authorizing the collection of rent capped at thirty per cent of the area median income level. [180] Testimony from the Governor's office specified a funding request of $50 million (Public testimony requests $50.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) per year for the Kauhale initiative, providing context for the previously blank appropriations. [45] HHFDC has also resubmitted its request for a $175,000 (Public testimony requests $175,000.00 (HB431_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-28-25_.PDF.txt)) FTE position to administer supportive housing provisions. [5]
